text: hi I'm dick Stevenson I'm the political
editor of the New York Times I'm joined
by Janet elder our polling director
Janet we have the first wave of exit
polls what do they tell us about the
issues and what's on voters minds well
we're seeing in these early votes that
the economy continued to dominate voters
voters Minds going into this day and
what about the overhang of the Bush
years how important has that been in the
way voters have responded to Obama's
call for change
McCain's efforts to distance himself
from the president well really what
we're we started to see the beginnings
of this campaign in the results of the
2006 exit polls and in those exit polls
we saw that voters both Democrats and
Republicans told us that they were angry
at George W Bush and that they were very
disappointed in his administration and
so we saw the Democrats win lard you
know have big victories in 2006 and that
kind of was one of the building blocks
for what we're seeing now we saw then in
Iowa for this campaign that change
trumped experience and that there was a
huge generational divide and we expect
to see those things continue the war was
the issue that was overwhelmingly on
people's minds when this campaign began
two years ago as it disappeared as an
issue how did that play into the
dynamics that you're talking about
that's right it was the dominant issue
for a very long time and then the
economy eclipsed it as the main issue on
voters minds and then we had all of the
events of September which only
exacerbated all of
sentiments that were there to begin with
Iraq has not disappeared off of the
public's agenda and and Barack Obama in
our latest polls before today had a
clear advantage on that issue the public
was opposed to the war and they sided
with Senator Obama on the issue were
over Senator McCain so I expect today
that we'll still see that there is a
smaller number of people who care and
are voting on the war and that those
people will probably favor
senator Obama and what can we say at
this point about the traits that voters
see in both of these candidates in terms
of leadership strengths and weaknesses I
think that after all of these many
months of campaigning that voters see
both men as leaders John McCain went
into this campaign having an advantage
on that evaluation but Barack Obama
really caught up after all of these
months of exposure in the many many long
months of the primary battle he began to
emerge and to be seen as a leader in the
public's mind after the debates he did a
lot better on that issue so my guess is
that today voters will see him maybe not
as as much of a leader as John McCain
but close to it Janet Eldar thanks a lot
I'm dick Stevenson political editor of
the New York Times thanks for joining us
